column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=Love in insects seeks similar expression to fear, and secretions, it is to be believed, furnish suitable means of intercourse,
#Text=especially in fragrance-loving creatures like butterflies.
#Text=Quite
#Text=lately Dr.
#Text=Fritz Muller, who is prosecuting entomological
#Text=research in the virgin forests of Brazil, stated that he was
#Text=brought to consider as sexual organs for the diffusion of odours
#Text=the various pencils, tufts and manes of hair, and the chalky,
#Text=silky, or velvety spots of peculiar scales, as well as the recurved
#Text=margin or other pouches enclosing pale buff or white down,
#Text=which distinguish the wings of many of the brilliant exotic
#Text=male butterflies.
#Text=And in a general way this assumption is by
#Text=no means improbable ; for although instances occur where these

#Text=insignia appear in the opposite sex in measure, and, as evolutionists would state it, acquired by the males, they have been transmitted in the lapse of time to their consorts, yet otherwise, in a
#Text=majority of cases, they seem truly masculine.
#Text=In the Papilionidae,
#Text=for instance, the front wings of the males have sometimes an
#Text=oval chalky spot on their under side, opposite to which there is
#Text=a dark brownish spot on the upper side of the hind wings, both
#Text=spots emitting a strong disagreeable odour.
#Text=At other times, the
#Text=scent spot on the fore wings is replaced by a brush of hair, and
#Text=that on the hind wing is chalky and fragrant of musk, as may
#Text=be seen in the common canary-coloured butterflies of the tropics,
#Text=Callidryas.
#Text=Here likewise the females show on either side of
#Text=their anal organs a shining spot odoriferous of a volatile acid.
#Text=A third example we may find in the male of our English
#Text=Clouded Yellows, where the chalky spot is seen without the
#Text=brush, the pot of rose-water without the sprinkler.
#Text=In other
#Text=genera certain “ plumules/ '  or club-shaped scales, fringed with
#Text=fine hair, have been accused of possessing scent properties.
#Text=Our
#Text=small White Butterfly, belonging to one of these, has a male,
#Text=according to Kirby, redolent of thyme, and with some of his
#Text=exotic fraternity the scent is described by Dr.
#Text=Muller as
#Text=delicious; but in such cases a caution, as Professor Westwood
#Text=has noticed, is doubtless needful, for may not these bright
#Text=beings that bathe in sunlight and vapoury distillations the livelong day, gather odour as they fly about.
#Text=We have many moths,
#Text=likewise, with raised scales on the wing-surface, but I am not
#Text=aware this is the source of scent attraction.
#Text=Lastly, organs of
#Text=perfume are said to exist in the sub-family of the Swallow Tails
#Text=along the anal margin of the hind wings of the males, which is
#Text=then recurved.
#Text=They are evinced by a tuft of hair with a
#Text=disagreeable odour.
#Text=In the Nymphalidae, or great group of butterflies with rudimentary forelegs, we find some of the common cosmopolitan
#Text=Dana ' inse have dactylate hollow processes at the abdominal
#Text=extremity, which are furnished with hairs, and on protrusion
#Text=emit a disagreeable odour ; and sexual pouches, possibly in
#Text=connection, exist on the first median nervure of the hind wing in a
#Text=few species ; both being seen in the tawny Danais, that extends
#Text=its range to Southern Europe.
#Text=Others of the Ithonia group
#Text=have a tuft of long hair near the anterior margin of the hind
#Text=wings, sometimes common to the sexes, and flavouring of vanilla,
#Text=while the males have a brown spot covered by the tuft.
#Text=The
#Text=spot and brush of the Yellow Callidryas are reproduced in one of
#Text=the Satyrinse, and in some of the Nymphalinse ; while in the
#Text=male of the blue Ageronia Arethusa a rather strong odour is
#Text=emitted by two large brown spots, situated between the wings,
#Text=which appear absent in others of this musical genus.
#Text=The
#Text=gdorious blue satin Morphos, the pride of Brazilian forest trees,
#Text=have protrusible hemispherical anal appendages, which sometimes are odoriferous of vanilla ; and in the Brassolinse, another
#Text=bulky South American progeny, pencils of erectile hairs or spots
#Text=of scales are present.
#Text=So, too, the peculiar long-winged ITeliconinse of the glades have scent organs in the male, situated
#Text=between the anal valves, and in the female these are placed on
#Text=the dorsal side of the abdominal extremity; but some have also
#Text=a scent-brush, if conclusion may be drawn from a figure in the
#Text=volume on “ Foreign Butterflies,” belonging to the Naturalist ' s
#Text=Library series.
#Text=But Didonis Biblis , according to Dr.
#Text=Muller, is, so far as odours
#Text=are concerned, the most interesting of all these fairy-formed and
#Text=many-coloured things of the tropical bush.
#Text=On seizing one of
#Text=these butterflies of either sex, it pushes from between the fourth
#Text=and fifth segment of the abdomen two hemispherical protuberances producing a disagreeable odour; and the male has a
#Text=second pair between the fifth and sixth segments of the
#Text=abdomen, while a different musk-like odour is produced by a
#Text=black spot beneath the front wings.
#Text=In the tailed Hair Streaks
#Text=the sexual spot that may be seen on the disc of the front wings
#Text=of the female of our green sort, is said to be odorous; and if
#Text=so, this is a singular instance of a scent secretion supplanting
#Text=a fixed wing colour.
#Text=The Skipper Butterflies, diurnal over our northern hills and
#Text=woodland, amid the scorching tropical glare are known as
#Text=evening visitors, stealing mysteriously to hang at the garden
#Text=lupins in purple dusk, before a reflex light has awoke a second
#Text=
#Text=and chaotic dawn.
#Text=They neither in colour as a rule bear the
#Text=burnish and talismanic impress of the sunlight, or in form do
#Text=they attain the feathery etherealness of the day fliers; their
#Text=antennae and various organs seem fairly heavy and moth-like,
#Text=and moth-like also are the expansile scent pencils of hair that
#Text=garnish the hind tibiae of the legs of many of the males.
#Text=Passing to the Burnet kind, a like incarnation of the union of
#Text=night and day, the males of exotic Glaucopidae have two long
#Text=retractable filaments, generally beset with hairs, on the ventral
#Text=side of the abdomen, sometimes emitting a strong odour.
#Text=Bristling scent pencils, however, are most characteristic of the
#Text=moths, and these usually distinguish the males, although, being
#Text=commonly retained in their pouches, their presence is little suspected until they have been pricked out with a needle-point ;
#Text=but in the twilight Sphinges, especially quick of nerve, they are
#Text=sometimes found present in both sexes, and sharp fear, as we
#Text=touch or grasp the ilower-hoverer reposing in diurnal lethargy,
#Text=will cause their momentary expansion.
#Text=Thus when the male
#Text=Death ' s-Head Moth is on the point of Squeaking in our fingers,
#Text=as its abdomen inflates, a sessile pencil of yellow hair starts from
#Text=a fold between the dorsal and ventral arcs at the base (Plate V.,
#Text=Fig. 7b), expanding to a stellate form with swift whirling
#Text=motion, like a trundled mop (Fig. 7a) ; and immediately there
#Text=arises an oily volatile effluvia, resembling the scent of jessamines,
#Text=but soon becoming nauseous.
#Text=This fluid aroma, secreted near
#Text=the insertion of the “ fans," and traversing by capillary attraction
#Text=to their extremity, stains them bright orange at the glands,
#Text=shaded into yellow at their tip.
#Text=anatomy has been investigated by Prof.
#Text=composed of hexagonally nucleated pyriform cells, from each
#Text=of which proceeds a tube to the base of the several hairs of the
#Text=fascicle, which are inserted by means of a process; so that the
#Text=unicellular glandules secrete the odoriferous matter, and the
#Text=hairs become their excretory ducts.
#Text=said to exist in the male Privet Hawk Moth, and may characterise the genus Sphinx.
